channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Laura Loomer’s far-right rhetoric has repelled many would-be MAGA allies, with one notable exception: Trump himself
item.description: People around the former president apparently see Loomer — an anti-Islam, anti-immigration activist — as a liability at a time when Donald Trump’s campaign (if not the candidate himself) is making a conscious effort to make their man appear less extreme, according to several sources close to the campaign’s inner circle. Still, Loomer is dead set on landing a role in a second Trump administration.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Chris Pratt’s demolition of a historic home to build a modern farmhouse is part of a disturbing trend
item.description: Few people realized the Zimmerman House in Los Angeles was in any danger before it was unceremoniously razed by the actor and his wife, author Katherine Schwarzenegger, who bought the mid-century home and its nearly one-acre plot last year for $12.5 million. Increasingly, preservationists say, these demos are not driven by changing tastes but rather by Americans’ ravenous appetites for larger and larger homes.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: 25 protesters at University of Virginia arrested after violent clash with police
item.description: The university said 25 pro-Palestinian demonstrators at the University of Virginia were arrested, after law enforcement officers in riot gear surrounded a student encampment that the administration said was prohibited

item.title: Mystik Dan finishes first in a photo finish in the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby
item.description: The Derby field at Churchill Downs on Saturday also included Dornoch, who is co-owned by former MLB star Jayson Werth, and Fierceness, a colt trained by Todd Pletcher. The Triple Crown continues with the Preakness Stakes on May 18 and the Belmont Stakes on June 8.

item.title: Frank Stella, celebrated artist of minimalist power, dies at 87
item.description: Stella achieved early fame with a series of monochromatic paintings that helped establish minimalism as an alternative to abstract expressionism in the late 1950s. He then spent the next several decades creating colorful works that seemed to repudiate his youthful principles.

item.title: ‘Abnormal and unprecedented’: Surge in sea level rise is imperiling the American South
item.description: Americans from Texas to North Carolina are grappling with one of the most rapid sea level surges on Earth, one that is choking septic systems, swallowing roads and drowning wetlands. Search The Post’s data to see how sea levels have changed across the region.

item.title: It’s not the Kentucky Derby without a mint julep. Here are six ways to make one.
item.description: It’s not the Kentucky Derby without a mint julep. Here are six ways to make one.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: Responding to microaggressions is taking a toll on me. Can I stop?
item.description: Ask Sahaj: Responding to microaggressions is taking a toll on me. Can I stop?

item.title: More senior homes refuse to pick up fallen residents, dialing 911 instead: ‘Why are they calling us?’
item.description: Frustrated cities and states have begun fining facilities for nonemergency calls, but some just keep calling.

item.title: The children who seem to remember past lives
item.description: What happens when a toddler is haunted by memories that aren’t theirs? The phenomenon, with its aura of the paranormal, has long been fodder for books, academic studies and dramatized documentaries. But there is no scientific means to conclusively prove — or disprove — a mechanism that might explain how a person could recall living a past life.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Claims of sexual assault, violence: How the myth of Sean Combs came undone
item.description: Diddy’s downfall built up slowly and then arrived dizzyingly fast, as rumors and accusations turned into lawsuits, raids and a decaying of Combs’s empire.

item.title: U.S. tells Qatar to evict Hamas political leaders if militant group obstructs Israeli deal for Gaza cease-fire, hostage release
item.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken delivered the message to Qatar’s prime minister, Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani, last month, said a U.S. official. Diplomats familiar with the situation said the Gulf emirate, which has hosted Hamas’s political leaders for years at the United States’ request, has anticipated the request for months and advised them to devise a backup plan.

item.title: Canada arrests three men in killing of Sikh separatist, an official says; Trudeau linked killing to Indian government
item.description: The three men are Indian Canadians believed to be part of an organized crime network acting on the behalf of the Indian government and its intelligence apparatus, according to the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a sensitive law enforcement matter. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau told lawmakers in September that authorities were pursuing “credible allegations” that agents of the Indian government were behind the killing of Hardeep Singh Nijjar last June in Surrey, British Columbia. Nijjar, a Canadian citizen, advocated for an autonomous Sikh state in India.

item.title: Rep. Henry Cuellar (D-Tex.) and his wife charged with accepting $600,000 in bribes from foreign companies
item.description: The congressman and his wife, Imelda Cuellar, are accused of setting up front companies that entered into sham contracts with an oil company controlled by the Azerbaijan government and a bank headquartered in Mexico. In a statement, Cuellar said he is innocent and will continue his campaign for another term.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: My boyfriend’s closest confidante is his on-again, off-again ex
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: My boyfriend’s closest confidante is his on-again, off-again ex

item.title: Prosecutors question Hope Hicks on ‘Access Hollywood’ tape that they say helped lead to hush money payment. Follow our coverage.
item.description: Called as a witness in Donald Trump’s New York hush money trial, the former aide told jurors she was “stunned” by the release of a hot mic tape in which Trump made light of forcing himself on women.

item.title: A Texas man’s ex-partner left the state to get an abortion. Now he’s asking a court for permission to investigate.
item.description: The previously unreported legal action reflects a potential new antiabortion strategy to block women from traveling to end their pregnancies in states where abortion is legal.

item.title: 10 questions, plus a bonus wager! It’s the weekend edition of On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: The economy added 175,000 jobs in April, as labor market growth slowed, compared to earlier in the year
item.description: Despite high interest rates, the labor market continues to show resilience in 2024, according to the latest data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

item.title: Trump trial. Campus protests. Jobs report. Boeing whistleblower. Hottest April. Russian TikTok. Kentucky Derby. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Stephen A. Smith and his naked-as-ever ambition are testing just how much of the ESPN star America wants
item.description: Sports, politics, sex, SpongeBob: There’s nothing Smith won’t argue about — as long as you keep listening.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Will request for a postnup offend much younger wife?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Will request for a postnup offend much younger wife?

item.title: Biden expands boundaries of two national monuments in California, protecting land that Native American tribes consider sacred
item.description: President Biden signed two proclamations enlarging the San Gabriel Mountains National Monument and the Berryessa Snow Mountain National Monument, using his executive authority to protect vast swaths of land of cultural significance to tribes and nearby communities.

item.title: A botched drone strike in Syria killed a civilian, not a terrorist as the U.S. first claimed, Defense Department acknowledges
item.description: The U.S. military’s findings, to be released later Thursday, follow a Washington Post investigation that cast doubt on its initial assertion the operation last year targeted a senior al-Qaeda figure. A Defense Department official said the real suspect got away.

item.title: Biden urges campus protesters to refrain from violence and says demonstrations have not changed his policies
item.description: The president called on pro-Palestinian demonstrators at campuses around the country to avoid chaos and intimidation, saying that Americans have a right to peaceful protest but strongly condemning some of the tactics that have been used. “We’ve all seen the images, and they put to the test two fundamental American principles,” Biden said in quickly scheduled remarks at the White House. “The first is the right to free speech and for people to peacefully assemble and make their voices heard. The second is the rule of law. Both must be upheld.”

item.title: Wait, a baseball game was delayed by what?! Find out in today’s On the Record.
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Body of fifth victim in Baltimore bridge collapse has been recovered, authorities say
item.description: The victim, one of six construction workers who died when the Key Bridge collapsed, was identified as Miguel Angel Luna Gonzalez, 49, of Glen Burnie, Md.

item.title: UCLA protests. Arizona abortion. Mike Johnson. Harvey Weinstein. Bird flu. Menopause drugs. Missing cat. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: This middle school’s battle against cellphones yielded surprising results
item.description: Illing Middle School in Manchester, Conn., navigated objections from students and some parents to lock up cellphones in a bid to improve focus and reduce social media-fueled conflicts. What unfolded reflects a broader struggle underway in education as some administrators turn to increasingly drastic measures to limit the reach of a technology that is both ubiquitous and endlessly distracting.

item.title: House passes divisive antisemitism bill as Republicans seek to crack down on campus protests over Gaza war
item.description: Critics of the Antisemitism Awareness Act, which has some Democratic support, call the legislation an effort to silence opinions of Israel and an affront to the First Amendment. It’s unclear what the bill’s prospects are in the Democratic-controlled Senate.

item.title: GOP-led Arizona Senate votes to repeal Civil War-era abortion ban. The Democratic governor is expected to sign it into law.
item.description: The state’s highest court revived the ban on nearly all abortions in early April and it was set to take effect in June. The repeal is expected to be signed into law by Gov. Katie Hobbs in the coming days, but the state attorney general’s office said the repeal would not take effect until 90 days after the legislature adjourns for the summer. So, barring successful court challenges, the 1864 ban could take effect for a short time in the state.

item.title: Federal Reserve leaves interest rates unchanged as rising inflation reduces pressure for cuts
item.description: Since the start of the year, hotter-than-expected price data has complicated officials’ plans for taking pressure off the economy.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Too late to accept a decade-old apology, accidentally left unread?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Too late to accept a decade-old apology, accidentally left unread?

item.title: Live chat: Can a restaurant charge us $900 two months before dinner? Our food critic responds and answers your questions.
item.description: Live chat: Can a restaurant charge us $900 two months before dinner? Our food critic responds and answers your questions.

item.title: A landmark study scared women away from menopause hormone treatments. A 20-year follow-up has found fears were largely overblown.
item.description: A new analysis published in JAMA found that for many younger menopausal women — typically those under 60 — the benefits of the drugs probably outweigh the risks for the short-term treatment of menopause symptoms. The analysis shows that younger women starting menopause and experiencing symptoms can take hormone treatments for several years with a lower likelihood of adverse effects.

item.title: Despair at Florida clinic as 6-week abortion ban — expected to be the biggest jolt to access since Dobbs — takes effect
item.description: At one Fort Lauderdale-area abortion clinic, women crowded the waiting room in the final hours Tuesday before the ban took effect. More than 80,000 women get an abortion in Florida in a typical year, accounting for about 1 in 12 abortions nationwide.

item.title: About 300 protesters were arrested at Columbia University and City College overnight, NYC Mayor Eric Adams says
item.description: Officers in riot gear on Tuesday night cleared Hamilton Hall on Columbia’s campus, which was occupied by pro-Palestinian protesters, as demonstrators and authorities continue to face off on campuses across the nation.

item.title: A baffling artifact in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene says she will move to oust Speaker Mike Johnson. The House is likely to consider the motion next week.
item.description: The move came after weeks of threats from Greene (R-Ga.), angry that Johnson (R-La.) has worked with Democrats to pass key legislation.

item.title: Columbia arrests. Trump penalty. Florida abortion ban. Marijuana. Debt relief. Student phones. Roman mystery. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: New York police enter Columbia University after pro-Palestinian demonstrators occupied a campus building. Follow our live coverage.
item.description: Officers wearing riot gear were holding zip ties on their way to the encampment where students were demanding that the Ivy League university divest from Israeli-linked companies more than six months into that country's war with Hamas.

item.title: Federal judges strike down Louisiana's new congressional map, saying second majority Black district is unconstitutional
item.description: The panel ruled Tuesday that a newly redrawn congressional map, which added a second majority Black district, violated the Equal Protection Clause and blocked the state from using the map in upcoming elections. The Louisiana legislature approved the new map in January after a federal court found that the existing map probably illegally diminished Black voting power.

item.title: A hidden force supercharged this Alabama flood — and threatens the American South
item.description: The U.S. Southeast and Gulf coasts are experiencing one of the world’s worst bursts of sea level rise, turning some storms into flooding disasters, a Washington Post analysis found.

item.title: Are most Americans getting more sleep than you? See how you compare.
item.description: Americans gained 10 minutes of sleep per day, on average, between 2019 and 2022, but that extra time was not evenly shared. The biggest sleep gains were seen in younger adults between the ages of 25 and 34, men of all ages and people without children, according to a Post analysis of data from the American Time Use Survey.

item.title: DEA plans to reclassify marijuana as a lower-risk drug, officials say — a major move that would ease access nationwide
item.description: The move by the Drug Enforcement Administration, first reported by the Associated Press, must receive approval from the White House Office of Management and Budget. Such a decision would not legalize marijuana at the federal level but could broaden access for medicinal use and boost the cannabis industry in states where the drug is legal.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Her family left all the kitchen work to her, so she went on strike
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Her family left all the kitchen work to her, so she went on strike

item.title: Israeli forces killed World Central Kitchen aid workers in Gaza. Here’s why we’re going back, chef José Andrés writes.
item.description: We’re going back to Gaza to feed people. Here’s what we need from Israel.
